ln The early developmenT of ChaeTopTerus eggs, The firsT discernible evenT is
The TormaTion of The firsT polar body, which appears aT l4~l5 minuTes in 50% of The
eggs aT 2l?C. This is Tollowed by The second polar body aT 27 minuTes, The "pear
shaped sTage" aT 46 minuTes, The polar lobe bulge, 52 minuTes; cleavage wiTh
polar lobe aTTached, 58 mibuTes; cleavage compleTe wiTh polar lobe reserved
inTo one blasTomere, 62 minuTes; and The 4-cell sTage 82 minuTes.
NoTe during developmenT To The 2-cell sTage The changes in shape ThaT The egg
undergoes. WhaT could These mean? Keep a few ChaeTopTerus larvae To observe
Trochophore sTages. 
SPISULA SOLIDISSIMA
Small specimens of The surf-clam ?pisula.solidissimagcan be found locally and may
be maTure from laTe in May Through AugusT. The larger specimens more generally
used come from The colder waTer on The norTh side of The Cape. For This reason,
There is some difficulTy in keeping These animals in good condiTion in The labora-
Tory. when placing These animals in The Tanks, iT is necessary To hold Them
each under waTer for a few seconds wiTh siphons up To expell gas Trapped in
Their gill chambers; wiThouT This riTual, The animals sufficaTe.
Large numbers of gameTes can be obTained by breaking The shell near The umbo,
cuTTing The adducTor muscles and removing The visceral mass and fooT inTacT. The
gonad is exposed by Trimming The gills and cuTTing direcTly inTo The visceral mass.
The ovary or pieces of The ovary are placed in an made by cuTTing off
The boTTom of a plasTic cenTrifuge Tube (diameTer inch and fasTening a circle of
bolTing cloTh To The inverTed lip by means of an elasTic band. FilTered sea waTer
is Then poured over The ovary in The egg sTrainer and eggs pass Through The
sTrainer inTo a beaker, leaving The ovarian Tissue and oTher debris behind. Eggs
should be allowed To seTTle in The beaker, and The supernaTanT should be decanTed.
This procedure should be repeaTed aT leasT Three Times. The use of a siphon for
removing The supernaTanT resulTs in less loss of eggs, alThough iT is a good idea
To lose some of The lighTesT eggs, as These are probably The leasT maTure.
Excised TesTes should be cuT up and placed on a 5 inch square double layer of
cheesecloTh which has previously been weT wiTh pyrex disTilled waTer and wrung dry.
The corners of The cheesecloTh are Then gaThered and TwisTed To press The seminal
fluid ouT of The bag so formed and inTo a dry dish, This can be covered and kepT
refrigeraTed for aT leasT 24 hours and possibly longer. This "dry" sperm is diluTed
drop To IO ml. Tor The sTock suspension, and To 3 drops oT This is used To
inseminaTe eggs in IO ml. of sea waTer, The quanTiTy of sperm varying wiTh The
number of eggs and The purpose of The experimenT. Spisula eggs are very suscepTible
To polyspermy; The presence of more Than Two pronuclei aT abouT 50 minuTes afTer
inseminaTion is a good criTerion of polyspermy. Spiscula eggs are also very
sucepTib|e To crowded condiTions; These can lead To delayed or inhibiTed miTosis
(see Allen, l952D.
The eggs of Spisula solidissima are in some respecfs similar To eggs of MacTra
sTulTorum, which were described early in The cenTury by KosTanecki aT Naples.
Early workers aT Woods Hole called The local clam "MacTra", even Though The name
Spisula had been given To iT in i838 by A True "MacTra" egg is available
in Florida. The Woods Hole Spisula egg has been used in only a few major sTudies;
SchechTor sTudied The aging responses in This egg, and more recenTly a sTudy of
ferTilizaTlon and arTificial acTivaTion was done by R. D. Allen.
The Spisula egg is abouT 56 microns in diameTer and quiTe Transparenf.
